summary.value:
In a previous study, we found that participants rated a Chinese applicant as more worthy or deserving of an Asian scholarship than both the Indian or Filipino applicants. (See pre-registration for the previous study: https://osf.io/nwzht/?view_only=c4cc021073d545ceb68a8a93bd601a7a). Additionally, the Chinese applicant was rated as having a stronger Asian identity and imagined to be more prototypically Asian looking than both the Indian and Filipino applicants. These findings support the hypothesis that East Asians, or Chinese individuals, are perceived as more representative of the overall Asian racial group than South Asians (e.g., Indian individuals), and Southeast Asians (e.g., Filipino individuals). 

In this follow-up study, we are testing the same hypothesis: whether people mentally represent prototypical “Asians” as East Asian (i.e. Chinese individuals) rather than as South Asian (i.e. Indian individuals) or Southeast Asian (i.e. Filipino individuals). However, we aim to more directly examine the proposed mechanism by showing that this effect appears when participants are asked to evaluate applicants in terms of how prototypically Asian the applicants are (or how well they “fit” the definition of what it means to be Asian) but does not emerge for a neutral/general type of evaluation. 

Please see attached pdf file for complete pre-registration of this study.

attributes.title: The influence of visual and hearing impairments on the experience in and maintenance of relationships (Sensory Loss in the Dyadic Context – SELODY)
attributes.description: The purpose of this project containing 3 studies is to investigate the influence of vision or combined vision/hearing loss of one partner on the couple relationship. The role of the disability in individual and dyadic adaptation is studied across a variety of variables. The aim of SELODY is to inform relatives, practitioners and the general public on how to best support couples who face a serious challenge such as vision and hearing impairment.

q1.value: The influence of visual and hearing impairments on the experience in and maintenance of relationships (Sensory Loss in the Dyadic Context – SELODY)

q2.value: Christina Jessica Breitenstein, Isabella Bertschi, Mirjam Kessler, Guy Bodenmann

q3.value:
Demographic developments in most Western countries are leading to a progressive aging of societies. Although the number of life years without disability is increasing due to advances in medical technology, the number of persons living with disability, often rooted in chronic disease, is growing. Sensory loss, especially vision loss, is one of the most common chronic conditions that cause disability. In Switzerland, an estimated 325.000 people are affected by a considerable vision loss, most of them in the form of acquired vision loss.
Although the level of disability related to the sensory loss varies depending on different factors within the individual and its context, the experience of sensory loss itself can be categorized as a critical and traumatic life event. Emotional reactions to vision loss include fear, helplessness and frustration. Reduced satisfaction with life, elevated risk for the development of depressive symptoms and negative views of the future may be correlates of experiencing sensory loss. Sensory loss in most cases significantly reduces an individual’s independence and leads to activity limitations and participation restrictions in a highly visual and acoustic environment.
A growing body of literature has shown that critical life events not only affect the individual but also the people close to them, especially romantic partners and family members. Lately, research on couples has focused on the effects of and coping with stress related to physical or mental illness of one partner. The concept of “we-disease” expresses the interdependence of both partners when coping with a major stressor. Both partners within the couple unit are affected by the practical and emotional implications the condition brings about. Indeed, the little research that has been published regarding romantic relationships in the context of sensory disability show that the emotional and practical implications of the disability can burden both partners individually, as well as the couple as a system. The impaired partner suffers due to his/her vision loss and loss of independence while the spouse is burdened with additional caretaking, and concerns for the safety and well-being of the impaired partner. 
However, as much as both partners and their relationship may be challenged, they can also both support each other and contribute to coping with the impacts of the disability. This idea is central to the concept of “we-disease” which posits that couples coping with illness or disability of one partner should be considered as a unit instead of dividing them into the traditional roles of patient and partner.
Mutual support, shared coping responsibility and joint coping efforts have been identified as beneficial factors in the context of individual and dyadic adaptation to stressors. More specifically, the concept of dyadic coping has been linked to a variety of positive outcomes at the individual and the dyadic level such as higher well-being and relationship satisfaction. A few studies have begun to examine dyadic coping in the context of chronic illness. The project at hand aims to extend this literature to couples coping with sensory loss, particularly vison loss.

q4.value:
Main research questions: 
1) How does vision loss or dual sensory loss (loss of vision and hearing) of one partner psychologically affect (a) the partner with sensory loss, (b) the spouse and (c) the couple relationship? 
2) What are resources that help both partners adapt to the sensory loss and maintain the mental health of both partners?

Main hypotheses:
Own and partner dyadic/shared appraisals of the disability are positively related to individual and dyadic functioning as reported by oneself and by the partner. These associations are mediated by self- and partner-reported levels of common/joint dyadic coping (CDC) with CDC being positively related to both the predictor and the outcome.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The research questions will be addressed by questionnaires distributed to both partners of the couple on two occasions at intervals of one year (1-year longitudinal design). The questionnaires are made available online or as paper-pencil-versions with accessibility adaptations to fit the target population. Telephone interviews conducted by study staff are another option to complete the survey to ensure every participant can participate individually without depending on their partner. Questionnaires will be available in German, French, and Italian.
An add-on study with a subsample from the survey study will consist of home visits to the couples. The couples will be instructed to have three video-taped discussions without the presence of the investigators. Two 8-minute discussions will be about stressors external to the relationship. A 10-minute discussion about the consequences of the vision loss of one partner for the couple relationship will follow. Videos will be coded by trained research assistants using established coding schemes.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value:
Recruitment is conducted in close cooperation with the Swiss National Association of and for the Blind. The study will be advertised trough magazine ads, mailing lists, self-help groups and counselling centers for people with visual impairment in German-, French- and Italian-speaking Switzerland as well as in Germany, France and Austria. Detailed information for participation in the study are provided by phone and on a study homepage (www.selody.ch). 
Participants interested in the study are directed to the study team at University of Zurich to sign up for participation. The study team checks the following inclusion criteria: a) a committed relationship of at least 6 months duration, b) both partner agree to participate in the study c) one partner is affected by visual impairment or combined vision and hearing impairment that has occurred or remarkably worsened during the course of the relationship, and d) the other partner is not affected by disability or serious health problems. Due to the high sensitivity for discrimination of the study population, the criteria b) and d) are applied flexibly and couples not meeting it can participate upon explicit request. However, we reserve the right to exclude certain persons or couples from the analysis for the investigation of certain research questions.
Depending on the participants’ wish, the declaration of consent with the complete study information are sent to the participants’ home or made available online, as this makes it possible for visually impaired persons to have the page read out electronically. Both partners are contacted individually and give their informed consent individually.
Every person is assigned an individual ID to allow anonymization of the data once data collection is finished. Furthermore, every couple is assigned a dyad-ID to ensure data of the partners can be linked during data analysis.

Upon completing the first survey, all participating individuals living in German-Speaking Switzerland will be asked if they are interested in receiving further information on an add-on study involving video-taped home visits. Those who are interested are provided with detailed information for participants and a consent form. If both partners give consent to participate, the couple will be included in the add-on study. The contents of all video and audio recordings will be blinded to the research assistants making the home visits. Videos are cut and coded by research assistants not involved in conducting the home visits.

q13.value:
Survey study: approx. 120 couples = 240 individual data sets
Add-on study (home visits): approx. 40 couples

q14.value:
The sample size for the survey was defined, due to the expected number of couples meeting the inclusion criteria that can be reached by the funding agency and the number of dyads needed for dyadic data analysis models such as Actor-Partner-Interdependence Models. 
The sample size for the add-on study was defined by an estimation of the potential sampling pool.

q15.value: Data collection for the first wave is planned from May 2019 to the end of December 2019. It is assumed that an exhaustive number of couples meeting the inclusion criteria can be reached during this period. Against this background, it can be assumed that further recruitment beyond this period would not result in more participating couples. Recruitment is therefore ceased after this period. For the second wave, the couples who participated in the first wave will be contacted again after one year and invited to the second part of the survey. For the add-on study, all individuals who consent to receiving further information on the home visits will be contacted. Recruitment for the add-on study will stop either when all potential participating couples have participated or end of February 2020 to avoid overlaps with the second survey wave.

question.value: Not applicable.

The study will investigate outcomes on several levels:
-	Functioning: Based on the International Classification of Functioning and Disability’s (ICF) understanding of disability, participants will answer questions regarding how well they are able to execute activities of daily life to estimate the impact of the sensory loss on functioning.
-	Individual psychological adaptation: Individual well-being and depressive symptoms as well as perceived chronic stress will be assessed.
-	Dyadic adaptation: On a dyadic level, relationship quality and we-ness will be assessed. 
-	Dyadic coping: To assess whether couples jointly cope with one partner’s sensory loss, their appraisals of the sensory loss as a shared stressor (we-disease appraisal), their willingness to talk about the sensory loss with their partner and their general ways of dealing with stress as a couple (dyadic coping) are assessed.
-	Communication: To further assess the relevance of the sensory loss in daily life, conversation topics will be coded from short audio files recorded when participants go about their everyday life. Coding of the audio files will include the use of we- vs. I-/you-talk (an observable measure for a shared focus or we-ness respectively) and the level of emotional depth of conversations.
Still open.

We will use an Actor-Partner-Interdependence-Mediation Model (APIMeM) with the predictor "shared appraisal", the mediator "common/joint dyadic coping" and the outcome "relationship satisfaction". The partners will be treated as distinguishable dyad members based on their role (directly affected by sensory loss vs. not directly affected by sensory loss).

q23.value: In dyadic analyses, dyads with responses from one partner only will be excluded.

q24.value: Several exploratory tests will be run to determine predictors of dyadic/shared appraisals and to establish possible outcomes and mediators affected by shared/dyadic appraisals of the sensory loss.

attributes.title: The Role of Executive Function in Moderating the Relationship Between Hearing Loss and Gait Speed
attributes.description: This project will use test to see if there is an interaction between hearing loss and executive function on gait speed. We will use objective measures of hearing status, gait speed and executive function from the Baltimore Longitudinal Study of Aging (BLSA)

q1.value: The moderating role of executive function in the relationship between hearing status and gait speed

q3.value:
The number of adults aged over 60 is projected to be 85.7 million by the year 2050(1). Slow gait, especially in older adults, is associated with adverse health outcomes including dementia(2, 3) and mortality(4). Understanding contributing factors to slow gait may be beneficial for developing preventative interventions. One area of potential intervention is in the realm of hearing loss. Prior studies have shown that hearing loss is associated with slow gait speed(5-7). However, the relationship is modest. One possible explanation is that this relationship may be moderated by cognitive function or status. 

In older adults, cognitive function has been associated with both hearing status and gait speed. Worse cognitive function, especially executive function, is strongly associated with slower gait speed (5, 6, 8-10). Recent evidence has shown that hearing loss is associated with accelerated cognitive declines in executive function(9), as well as other cognitive domains (9-13). It may be hypothesized that older individuals with worse hearing and poorer executive function would have slower gait speed. Gaining a better understanding of relationships among hearing impairment, cognitive status, and gait speed may be an essential step for developing interventions that improve mobility and eventually the overall quality of life among older adults.

1.	J Vespa, D Armstrong, Medina L. Demographic Turning Points for the United States: Population Projections for 2020 to 2060. US Department of Commerce Economics and Statistics Administration 2018:25-1144.
2.	Tian Q, Studenski S. Dismobility in Aging and the Role of Cognition and Health Consequences of Reduced Mobility. Montero-Odasso M, Camicioli R (eds) Falls and Cognition in Older Persons. 2020(Springer, Cham):21-33.
3.	Allali G, Launay CP, Blumen HM, Callisaya ML, De Cock AM, Kressig RW, et al. Falls, Cognitive Impairment, and Gait Performance: Results From the GOOD Initiative. J Am Med Dir Assoc. 2017;18(4):335-40.
4.	Studenski S, Perera S, Patel K, Rosano C, Faulkner K, Inzitari M, et al. Gait speed and survival in older adults. JAMA. 2011;305(1):50-8.
5.	Li L, Simonsick EM, Ferrucci L, Lin FR. Hearing loss and gait speed among older adults in the United States. Gait Posture. 2013;38(1):25-9.
6.	Chen DS, Betz J, Yaffe K, Ayonayon HN, Kritchevsky S, Martin KR, et al. Association of hearing impairment with declines in physical functioning and the risk of disability in older adults. J Gerontol A Biol Sci Med Sci. 2015;70(5):654-61.
7.	Campos J, Ramkhalawansingh R, Pichora-Fuller MK. Hearing, self-motion perception, mobility, and aging. Hear Res. 2018;369:42-55.
8.	Peelle JE, Wingfield A. The Neural Consequences of Age-Related Hearing Loss. Trends Neurosci. 2016;39(7):486-97.
9.	Lin FR, Ferrucci L, Metter EJ, An Y, Zonderman AB, Resnick SM. Hearing loss and cognition in the Baltimore Longitudinal Study of Aging. Neuropsychology. 2011;25(6):763-70.
10.	Lin FR, Yaffe K, Xia J, Xue QL, Harris TB, Purchase-Helzner E, et al. Hearing loss and cognitive decline in older adults. JAMA Intern Med. 2013;173(4):293-9.
11.	Deal JA, Betz J, Yaffe K, Harris T, Purchase-Helzner E, Satterfield S, et al. Hearing Impairment and Incident Dementia and Cognitive Decline in Older Adults: The Health ABC Study. J Gerontol A Biol Sci Med Sci. 2017;72(5):703-9.
12.	Li KZH, Bherer L, Mirelman A, Maidan I, Hausdorff JM. Cognitive Involvement in Balance, Gait and Dual-Tasking in Aging: A Focused Review From a Neuroscience of Aging Perspective. Front Neurol. 2018;9:913.
13.	Livingston G, Sommerlad A, Orgeta V, Costafreda SG, Huntley J, Ames D, et al. Dementia prevention, intervention, and care. The Lancet. 2017;390(10113):2673-734.

q4.value: We hypothesize that the relationship between hearing status and gait speed depends on executive function. Specifically, the relationship between hearing loss and gait speed will be stronger in those with poor executive function.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Study population: cognitively normal participants aged 60 and older from the BLSA with concurrent data on hearing status, executive function, and 6-m gait speed. Individuals who are diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease, stroke, deafness, and have gait speed <0.6m/sec will be excluded. 

Independent variable: Hearing status will be measured using a pure tone average (PTA) of the better hearing ear (9). It will be used as both a continuous variable and a categorical variable following the World Health Organization (WHO) cutoffs (14). 

Moderator: Executive function will be measured using the Trail Making Test (TMT) part B, Delta TMT(15). 

Dependent variable: 6-m gait speed

Covariates: age, sex, race, education, height, body mass index (BMI), smoking history, cardiovascular disease, hypertension, and diabetes

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value: Data will only be used on cognitively normal participants aged 60 and older from the BLSA with concurrent data on hearing status, executive function, and 6-m gait speed. Multiple imputations may be used to increase the sample size if needed. Individuals who are diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease, stroke, deafness, and have gait speed less than 0.6m/sec will be excluded

q13.value: At this stage, it is difficult to say what the sample size will be, but it is highly probable that the number of subjects will be greater than 200.

question.value: Hearing status will be measured using pure-tone average (PTA) of the better hearing ear. This will be the average of 4 speech frequencies ranging from 500-4000Hz. Hearing loss (or impaired hearing) will be determined using the World Health Organization Cutoff of 25dB. Gait speed will be measured as part of the short physical performance battery of tests. This is a 6-meter walk in which the participant is timed. Executive function will be measured using The trail making test (TMT) parts B and B minus part A, also known as the delta TMT, and consideration will be given to the inclusion of the digit symbol substitution test (DSST). The analysis conducted will also be adjusted for demographic variables such as age, sex, race, years of education. As well as medical variables such as height, BMI, smoking history, CVD history, hypertension, and diabetes.

To test whether the relationship of PTA with gait speed depends on TMT part A or Delta TMT, we will first create an interaction term between PTA and TMT part A or Delta TMT. We will then test the interaction in a linear regression of  PTA predicting gait speed.

q23.value: Multiple imputations will be used to fill in missing data where possible.

registration_responses.q3:

Slow gait, especially in older adults, is associated with adverse health outcomes including dementia(2, 3) and mortality(4). Understanding contributing factors to slow gait may be beneficial for developing preventative interventions. One area of potential intervention is in the realm of hearing loss. Prior studies have shown that hearing loss is associated with slow gait speed(5-7). However, the relationship is modest. One possible explanation is that this relationship may be moderated by cognitive function or status. 

In older adults, cognitive function has been associated with both hearing status and gait speed. Worse cognitive function, especially executive function, is strongly associated with slower gait speed (5, 6, 8-10). Recent evidence has shown that hearing loss is associated with accelerated cognitive declines in executive function(9), as well as other cognitive domains (9-13). It may be hypothesized that older individuals with worse hearing and poorer executive function would have slower gait speed. Gaining a better understanding of relationships among hearing impairment, cognitive status, and gait speed may be an essential step for developing interventions that improve mobility and eventually the overall quality of life among older adults.

registration_responses.q4: We hypothesize that the relationship between hearing status and gait speed depends on executive function. Specifically, the relationship between hearing loss and gait speed will be stronger in those with poor executive function.
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to accessing the data
registration_responses.q13: At this stage, it is difficult to say what the sample size will be, but it is highly probable that the number of subjects will be greater than 200.
registration_responses.q23: Multiple imputations will be used to fill in missing data where possible.
registration_responses.q8.question:
Study population: cognitively normal participants aged 60 and older from the BLSA with concurrent data on hearing status, executive function, and 6-m gait speed. Individuals who are diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease, stroke, deafness, and have gait speed <0.6m/sec will be excluded. 

Independent variable: Hearing status will be measured using a pure tone average (PTA) of the better hearing ear (9). It will be used as both a continuous variable and a categorical variable following the World Health Organization (WHO) cutoffs (14). 

Moderator: Executive function will be measured using the Trail Making Test (TMT) part B, Delta TMT(15). 

Dependent variable: 6-m gait speed

Covariates: age, sex, race, education, height, body mass index (BMI), smoking history, cardiovascular disease, hypertension, and diabetes
registration_responses.q12.question: Data will only be used on cognitively normal participants aged 60 and older from the BLSA with concurrent data on hearing status, executive function, and 6-m gait speed. Multiple imputations may be used to increase the sample size if needed. Individuals who are diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease, stroke, deafness, and have gait speed less than 0.6m/sec will be excluded
registration_responses.q17.question: Hearing status will be measured using pure-tone average (PTA) of the better hearing ear. This will be the average of 4 speech frequencies ranging from 500-4000Hz. Hearing loss (or impaired hearing) will be determined using the World Health Organization Cutoff of 25dB. Gait speed will be measured as part of the short physical performance battery of tests. This is a 6-meter walk in which the participant is timed. Executive function will be measured using The trail making test (TMT) parts B and B minus part A, also known as the delta TMT, and consideration will be given to the inclusion of the digit symbol substitution test (DSST). The analysis conducted will also be adjusted for demographic variables such as age, sex, race, years of education. As well as medical variables such as height, BMI, smoking history, CVD history, hypertension, and diabetes.
registration_responses.q19.question: To test whether the relationship of PTA with gait speed depends on TMT part A or Delta TMT, we will first create an interaction term between PTA and TMT part A or Delta TMT. We will then test the interaction in a linear regression of  PTA predicting gait speed.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value:
We’ll collect additionally data with the ASQ (Berument et al., 1999); SIAS (Mattick & Clark, 1998) and NEO-FFI (Costa & McCrae, 1992). To this point, only an exploratory analysis with the data from the NEO-FFI is planned.
For exploratory purposes, we want to examine the relationship between social attention and personality characteristics. For these analyses we rely heavily on the Code provided by Kuhn (2017). To examine the relationship between social attention and personality characteristics, we’ll apply a support vector machine model with a radial basis kernel for each of the personality facets of the Neo-FFI, while using FD%social and FF%social of the laboratory context as predictors. We’ll tune these models over the cost-value, while estimating sigma with the R function kernlab::sigest. We are interested in the root mean square error (RMSE). Is the RMSE meaningfully above the RMSE of the predictions of a linear model with equivalent predictors and the RMSE obtained by just using the mean of the measurement of each personality facet and participant as predictor for this participant and facet?

We want to repeat this procedure while using the FD%social of the real-life social context as predictor. We are curious, if the high interaction potential of a real-life social situation does reveal eye-movements of social attention more gravitated to personality characteristics than in a laboratory context. 
Due to time constraints and restrictions (due to a low sample size and the usage of only a few predictors), these analyses will be just exploratory and no focal point of this study.

sample.value: For a correlation of .57 (the odd-even-reliability of session 2 of experiment 1 from Guy et al., 2019), a sig. level of 0.05 and a power of .85 (.99) we’ll need for a one tailed t-test at least n=20 (40) participants. To calculate the amount of observations needed we used R (R Core Team, 2019) with the r-package “pwr” (Champeley, 2018). We will aim for a sample size of at least 40, although we will limit data collection to a month due to time constraints of this being part of a bachelor thesis. We will stop data collection after one month if the sample size is >= 20.

analyses.value:
First, to examine hypothesis 1, we will calculate the odd-even-reliability (like Guy et al., 2019 did) of FD%social and FF%social for the first condition. We’ll use the Spearman-Brown-Formula due to the fact that by decreasing item numbers of one test the estimation of the reliability coefficient is going to be too conservative. After that, we will perform a permutation analysis with 1000 iterations, which is equivalent to calculate one thousand split half correlations, each time with different random halves of the image-set. FF%social and FD%social will be calculated separately for each half. This is done to control for unbalanced image features. At the end, we will calculate the intraclass correlation (ICC(2,1), Shrout & Fleiss, 1979) to see, if there is a considerable amount of interindividual variance in comparison to the amount of inter-image variance. 

Second, to examine hypothesis 2, we will calculate a pearson correlation between the FD%social in the laboratory context and the FD%social in the real-life social context. We will conduct a one-tailed z-test to see if the correlation is significantly beneath the test-retest-reliability of .57 obtained by Guy et al. (2019) in Experiment 2.

Third, to examine hypothesis 3, we will calculate a pearson correlation between the percentage of the display duration of social scenes per person and the FD%social as well as the FF%social of the laboratory context. Thereafter, we’ll conduct a one tailed t-test to see, if the correlation is significantly above zero.

outliers.value: We will exclude participants if technical difficulties occur, including a failure to calibrate the eye-trackers well (>1° deviance) or too many ( > 20%) missing data points in the eye-tracking data occur.

dependent.value:
Eye-tracking data will be recorded. The key dependent variables are the percentage of cumulative fixation durations on faces and heads (FD%social) and the percentage of cumulative first fixations on faces and heads (FF%social). These variables will be obtained by measuring the overall fixation duration/first fixations (which is the sum of fixation durations/first fixations over all images) and calculating the ratio of the sum of fixation durations/ first fixations on faces (heads) to the overall sum of fixation durations/ first fixations, multiplied with 100. The percentage of fixation duration on faces/heads in the real-life social context condition will be obtained similarly.
Finally, the ratio of the the sum of display duration (self-chosen exhibition time) of social scenes to the overall display duration of the images in condition 2 will be calculated.

conditions.value:
Participants will be assigned to three conditions: 
In the first condition (the laboratory context condition), participants will freely view 42 images of social scenes, each of which will be displayed for 10 seconds on a monitor.
In the second condition, participants will freely choose the duration of time each of 20 new images will be displayed. 10 images of this new set are social scenes, 10 images are not. 
In the third condition (the real social context condition), participants are asked to play “Where is Wally?”, whereby only eye-tracking-data collected under a waiting condition and while instructing participants for “Where is Wally?” will be used.

hypothesis.value:
Main question: Is social attention, i.e. the preference to attend to other people, a stable trait that generalizes over measures?

Hypothesis 1: Social attention is reliable and can be consistently measured in a laboratory context. In other words, participants who prefer to look at people in a picture of a complex social scene will tend to look at people in other scenes as well. 
Hypothesis 2: The generalizability of this (lab-based) measure to a more naturalistic context will be restricted. The correlation between the measure of social attention in the laboratory context and the real-life social context will be less than .57, which is the test-retest-reliability of social attention in a laboratory context over two weeks obtained by Guy et al. (2019).
Hypothesis 3: A predilection for heads and faces will generalize to a behavioral preference of social stimuli. Social attention as measured with eye-tracking in the lab will predict self-chosen exhibition to social stimuli.

attributes.title: Cautionary Vagueness and Probability Assessment in High-Stakes Decision Making

q1.value: Cautionary Vagueness and Probability Assessment in High-Stakes Decision Making

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Though almost all high-stakes decisions require assessing uncertainty, analysts and decision makers often discuss probability in vague ways (Erev and Cohen 1990, Wallsten and Budescu 1995). In areas such as medicine (Gigerenzer 2002), regulation (Sunstein 2007), climate science (Budescu et al. 2014), and national security (Johnston 2004), experts are typically uncomfortable expressing probabilities with numeric precision, and often avoid offering assessing uncertainty at all. Studying more than three thousand doctor-patient interactions, for instance, Braddock et al. (1999) found that physicians described uncertainty about treatment outcomes in 17 percent of complex procedures. In a review of 379 declassified National Intelligence Estimates, Friedman and Zeckhauser (2012) found that four percent of key judgments conveyed probability using quantitative expressions or phrasings with clear numeric equivalents. Vague probability assessments can have clear, negative consequences. In 1961, the Joint Chiefs of Staff determined that the proposed Bay of Pigs invasion was highly tenuous, estimating its chances of success as roughly one in three. But in their report to President John F. Kennedy, the Chiefs wrote only that “this plan has a fair chance of success,” which Kennedy took to indicate support for the proposal (Wyden 1979, 88-90). Similarly, in his post mortem review of the space shuttle Challenger explosion, Richard Feynman (1986) found that managers and engineers held estimates of rocket failure rates that differed, on average, by a factor of one thousand. Both cases demonstrated obvious miscommunication, generated sharp criticism, and raised the possibility that major crises could have been averted if public officials had made clearer probability assessments. In some fields, vague probability assessments are deliberately encouraged by official guidelines. For instance the U.S. Director of National Intelligence’s 2015 directive on “Analytic Standards” instructs intelligence analysts to assess likelihood using “words of estimative probability” that correspond to seven different segments of the number line. This spectrum helps to mitigate extreme miscommunication as in the Bay of Pigs example, but the difference is of degree and not kind. To use this guidance properly, analysts must quantify their judgments and then coarsen those judgments into vaguer, qualitative terms. A similar set of guidelines can be found in U.S. Army doctrine on “Composite Risk Management.” There are several reasons why many scholars and practitioners advocate qualitative probability expressions, but this project focuses on two of those arguments in detail. First, many scholars and practitioners argue that quantifying probability estimates would expose analysts to undue criticism when their estimates fall on the “wrong side of maybe.” Second, clear probability assessments might constrain decision makers’ freedom of action, as explicit expressions of doubt could make policy choices more difficult to sell to the public or more challenging to defend after the fact. Both of these arguments imply that even if quantitative probability assessments are ideal in principle, bureaucratic and political incentives prevent this idea from being implemented in practice. I refer to this idea as cautionary vagueness, which I define as the use of intentionally vague probability assessments as a strategy for mitigating criticism. Though the idea of cautionary vagueness appears widely in scholarship on national security decision making, I argue that there are two main reasons to question this strategy’s effectiveness. First, even if vague probability assessments mitigate blame in some contexts, they can also mitigate credit. When probability assessments fall on the “right side of maybe,” or when risky decisions succeed, public officials may have incentives to emphasize the clarity of their probabilistic reasoning. The logic of cautionary vagueness thus supposes that the benefits of blame avoidance outweigh the costs to credit-claiming. This is plausible, but it is an empirical claim that has never been tested directly, especially in a national security context. Second, it is not clear why quantitative probability assessments should expose analysts and decision makers to greater scrutiny than employing “words of estimative probability.” It would be one thing for analysts and decision makers to avoid making probability assessments at all: but if they do express probability, does calling a conclusion “likely” really invite less criticism than making an estimate of “65 percent”? In fact, numeric assessments could even mitigate criticism in some cases by dispelling impressions of misplaced certainty. Again, it is an open empirical question as to whether these countervailing effects alleviate or intensify blame on the whole. This project aims to provide the first systematic exploration of cautionary vagueness. The theoretical purpose of this project is to translate ideas about cautionary vagueness into falsifiable hypotheses (and to explain why those hypotheses are worth scrutinizing). I then test those hypotheses using original survey experiments asking respondents to evaluate the quality of analysis and decision making.

q16.value: Probability assessments are inherently difficult to evaluate. Consider a financial analyst who states that there is a 70 percent chance that a stock price will go up. If the stock price instead goes down, then we can say that the analyst’s estimate was on the “wrong side of maybe,” but there is rarely an objective way to know how much we should attribute this particular discrepancy to bad estimation versus bad luck. Nevertheless, many people naturally criticize estimates that fall on the wrong side of maybe, assuming that uncertain outcomes should have been predictable before the fact. This is called hindsight bias (Fischhoff 1975, Tetlock and Lebow 2001). Analysts may leave probability assessments intentionally vague so as to mitigate such criticism. Scholars of national security often reference this kind of cautionary vagueness. Mark Lowenthal (2006, 128-29), a scholar with three decades’ experience in the U.S. Intelligence Community, criticizes intelligence analysts for using “weasel words” to escape criticism, arguing that this behavior represents “analytical pusillanimity.” One way in which national security may be distinct from other areas of high-stakes decision making is that decision makers might also prefer for analysts to leave probability assessments vague. Dean Acheson (1969, 375), U.S. Secretary of State under President Harry Truman, argued that public officials must often make decisions “clearer than truth,” glossing over doubts in order to defend policy choices to the public. Joshua Rovner (2011) develops a theory of intelligence-policy relations which holds that decision makers aim to cherry-pick analyses in order to oversell their policies. This behavior relates to what scholars call outcome bias: the idea that many people naturally evaluate decision makers on the basis of whether or not their actions appear to have been successful (Baron and Hershey 1988, Gurdal, Miller, and Rustichini 2013). Combined with partisan pressures, outcome bias can lead critics to seize on any information that might raise doubts about the quality of a decision. Explicitly acknowledging uncertainty about a decision’s outcome may court this kind of pushback from critical constituencies. Understanding the use of probability in national security and other areas of high-stakes decision making thus requires grappling with cautionary vagueness, whether or not one approves of the practice. Yet there are two main reasons to question whether cautionary vagueness is as effective as the conventional wisdom supposes. First, even if precise probability assessments engender blame when estimates fall on the wrong side of maybe, they may also increase credit when estimates fall on the right side of maybe. Following the successful 2011 raid on Osama bin Laden’s compound in Pakistan, for instance, President Barack Obama and his advisers described to the media how they had parsed probability assessments about the chances that Al Qaeda’s leader was living in that location, including several debates involving numeric percentages. Presumably, White House and intelligence officials believed that this information would improve public perceptions of how carefully they had handled uncertainty. President Obama remarked in an interview regarding his decision making process for the bin Laden raid that, “one of the things you learn as president is that you’re always dealing with probabilities” (Bowden 2012, 161). All participants in this debate were eager to emphasize how this decision was surrounded by uncertainty. Cautionary vagueness thus only benefits public officials if quantifying probability assessments increases blame more than it increases credit. This is plausible: some scholars posit a general negativity bias in public affairs in which blame for bad outcomes tends to stronger than credit for good outcomes (Hood 2011, 9-14). But to date, this claim has not been tested in a national security context. A second reason to question the logic of cautionary vagueness is that precise probability assessments may actually mitigate some kinds of criticism. In the case of the L’Aquila earthquake, public officials were literally put on trial for making their assessments too vague. Similarly, the 2002 National Intelligence Estimate (NIE) on Iraq’s Continuing Programs for Weapons of Mass Destruction provides an example of how imprecise analysis can plausibly increase analysts’ blame exposure. The bumper-sticker summary of the Iraq NIE is that the U.S. Intelligence Community thought it was a “slam dunk” to conclude that Saddam Hussein was pursuing nuclear weapons. But the estimate itself does not say this – in fact, the NIE’s key judgments contain no direct statements about the likelihood that Iraq was developing nuclear weapons. Many key judgments refer to Iraq pursuit of “weapons of mass destruction,” which included biological and chemical weapons in addition to nuclear weapons. The NIE states that “in the view of most agencies, Baghdad is reconstituting its nuclear weapons program,” but the estimate includes a specific dissent on this point from the U.S. State Department and does not assess of the probability that this statement is true. To be sure, the information and assumptions presented in the NIE are widely mistaken, and the estimate seems designed to convince readers to believe that Iraq was actively pursuing a nuclear bomb. But this point is mostly implied: it is not stated explicitly, let alone accompanied by a clear probability assessment. Jervis (2006), among others, has thus argued that one of the most important flaws with the Iraq NIE is not just that its arguments were wrong but that the uncertainty surrounding those estimates was left vague. In hindsight, it is impossible to say how the U.S. Intelligence Community might have quantified the probability that Saddam Hussein was pursuing nuclear weapons in 2002. But even if the NIE’s authors had assessed this probability to be as high as 80 percent or 90 percent, this could not have been construed after the fact as a “slam dunk,” and it might have generated useful debate about the sources and implications of residual doubt. Consistent with this point, post-mortem reviews of Iraq WMD intelligence written by the U.S. Senate (2004, 16), the Silberman-Robb Commission (2005, 409, 419), and the UK’s Butler Review (2004, 145) all conclude that a major lesson from the episode is the need for clearer communication of uncertainty. Moreover, it is not at all obvious why numeric percentages should court more controversy than using the “words of estimative probability” that are currently recommended by the U.S. Director of National Intelligence. Unless analysts constantly use the term “even chance,” then employing words of estimative probability always runs a risk of falling on the wrong side of maybe. The question then becomes whether assessing a probability as “65 percent” would make analysts worse off than saying that some judgment is “likely” to be true. Again, this assumption is plausible, but unsupported by systematic evidence. Hypotheses I believe that the key questions about cautionary vagueness can be translated into six testable hypotheses. These hypotheses capture arguments about how quantifying probability assessments could either exacerbate or reduce public officials’ exposure to criticism. Where relevant, I explicitly distinguish mechanisms influencing analysts versus decision makers. Following a standard distinctions in the decision sciences, I define analysts as individuals providing probability assessments and decision makers as individuals who use that information to judge prospective actions. I use the term public officials to describe both analysts and decision makers together. Hypothesis 1: Quantifying probability assessments increases criticism. Many scholars and practitioners are inherently skeptical of quantifying subjective judgments. It is thus possible that quantifying probability assessments always exposes analysts and decision makers to criticism. If true, this argument would support the argument that public officials have incentives to leave probability assessments vague. Hypothesis 2: Quantifying probability assessments increases hindsight bias. Probability assessments are especially exposed to criticism when they fall on the “wrong side of maybe.” Many scholars and practitioners believe that quantitative assessments suggest an illusion of rigor that may exacerbate such criticism. If true, this argument would support the argument that analysts have an incentive to leave probability assessments vague. Hypothesis 3: Quantifying probability assessments increases outcome bias. Decision makers are especially exposed to criticism when their actions are unsuccessful. Quantifying probability assessments could exacerbate such criticism by emphasizing how decision makers knowingly took risky actions. If true, this argument would support the argument that decision makers have an incentive to prefer that probability assessments be left vague. Hypothesis 4: Quantifying probability assessments increases credit given to analysts who fall on the “right side of maybe.” If quantifying probability assessments exposes unlucky analysts to greater criticism, then this might also facilitate credit-claiming when those assessments appear to be confirmed by subsequent events. If true, this argument would imply that analysts may not always have incentives to leave probability assessments vague. Hypothesis 5: Quantifying probability assessments increases credit given to decisions with successful outcomes. If quantifying probability assessments creates an illusion of rigor surrounding analysis and decision making, this may work to decision makers’ credit when their actions are perceived to be effective. If true, this argument would imply that decision makers may not always have incentives to prefer that probability assessments be left vague. Hypothesis 6: Quantifying probability assessments expands blame more than it expands credit. If vague probability assessments entail countervailing effects with respect to blame avoidance versus credit-claiming, then a key question is whether either of these effects is clearly stronger on net. If the “negativity bias” holds, such that quantifying probability assessments generally expands blame more than credit, then this would support the argument that public officials have incentives to leave probability estimates vague.

q17.value: In order to test the hypotheses, I designed a survey experiment that presents respondents with either of two descriptive vignettes. The first vignette involves a special forces mission to rescue Americans held hostage by ISIS in Iraq. The second vignette involves a drone strike targeting Al Qaeda leaders in Yemen. Each vignette involves four paragraphs describing how intelligence analysts and national security decision makers assessed uncertainty. The first paragraph describes whether the operation succeeded or failed. For the hostage rescue mission, this paragraph explains either that U.S. special forces retrieved the hostages, or that they found the hostages were not present. Either way, U.S. forces sustained casualties in conducting the mission. In the drone strike vignette, the first paragraph explains either that the attack killed three senior Al Qaeda leaders or that it had mistakenly targeted a wedding party. Either way, civilians were killed in the attack, which generated local protests. The second paragraph of each vignette describes how “sources involved with planning the operation stressed that it was a difficult decision that required wrestling with uncertainty.” The paragraph describes several pieces of evidence on which intelligence analysts based their judgments. These pieces of evidence remain constant across scenario versions. The third paragraph of each vignette describes the probability that analysts assigned to the hostages being present, or to the targets of the drone strike being correctly identified. These assessments vary on two dimensions. First, some assessments were above fifty percent, and some were below fifty percent. Thus the scenarios randomly vary whether or not analysts proved to be on the “wrong side of maybe” (though the information on which they based their judgments was always presented identically). Second, some assessments are expressed using words (either “likely” or “unlikely”) and some assessments were expressed using numbers (either “65 percent” or “35 percent”). These probability assessments are each presented twice, highlighted in quotes. The third paragraph concludes with a quote from an unnamed official stating, “This was a probability thing, and we made sure to weigh the costs and benefits of this operation as thoroughly as possible.” The phrasing mimics a statement reportedly made by President Obama during a debate over the bin Laden raid, and is meant to reinforce the probabilistic nature of the decision. The fourth paragraph of each vignette, which remains constant across scenario versions, presents quotes from public officials stating that “we analyzed the evidence from every angle we could think of”; “In these kinds of situations, you have to be willing to take risks”; and “I supported this decision because I believed we could defend it no matter how the mission turned out.” Each respondent will be presented with only one version of only one vignette. After reading the vignette, respondents are asked to “Please write a few sentences describing how you believe you would have reacted to the uncertainty in this scenario if it had been your decision.” Then respondents are asked, “Based only on the information you read in this scenario, please indicate your level of agreement with each of the following statements.” The first statement is, “U.S. officials made the right decision.” The second statement is, “The intelligence analysis supporting this decision was sound.” Levels of agreement are recorded on seven-point scales with 1 defined as “Strongly Disagree,” 4 defined as “Neutral,” and 7 defined as “Strongly agree.” These response measures serve as the main dependent variables capturing support or criticism for this study. Asking about levels of agreement/disagreement is intended to avoid priming respondents by directly asking about levels of “support” or “blame” for their actions. After recording these responses, respondents receive two multiple-choice attention-check questions. The first question asks respondents to identify the outcome of the mission. The second question asks respondents to identify the probability that intelligence analysts attached to their assessment. Respondents who do not answer both questions correctly will be denied payment, and their responses will not appear in the data. After completing these attention-check questions, respondents complete a Berlin adaptive numeracy test (Cokely et al. 2012), and a short battery of demographic questions. I will conduct this experiment on Amazon MTurk, with an initial run of 2,000 respondents. This sample size is based on the following power calculation. -The experiment effectively involves four kinds of scenarios, based on a 2x2 division of (a) whether the decision was successful, and (b) whether analysts provided a favorable or unfavorable assessment. Within each scenario format, I am interested in the treatment effect of quantifying probability assessments. -With 2,000 respondents, there are 500 respondents per scenario format. I aim to identify a treatment effect of 0.5 points. If the standard deviation on each dependent variable is 2.0 (which would be a lot of variation on a 7-point scale), then I would have an 80% chance of capturing an 0.5-point treatment effect in each scenario format.

registration_responses.q1: Cautionary Vagueness and Probability Assessment in High-Stakes Decision Making
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any research activities
registration_responses.q15: Though almost all high-stakes decisions require assessing uncertainty, analysts and decision makers often discuss probability in vague ways (Erev and Cohen 1990, Wallsten and Budescu 1995). In areas such as medicine (Gigerenzer 2002), regulation (Sunstein 2007), climate science (Budescu et al. 2014), and national security (Johnston 2004), experts are typically uncomfortable expressing probabilities with numeric precision, and often avoid offering assessing uncertainty at all. Studying more than three thousand doctor-patient interactions, for instance, Braddock et al. (1999) found that physicians described uncertainty about treatment outcomes in 17 percent of complex procedures. In a review of 379 declassified National Intelligence Estimates, Friedman and Zeckhauser (2012) found that four percent of key judgments conveyed probability using quantitative expressions or phrasings with clear numeric equivalents. Vague probability assessments can have clear, negative consequences. In 1961, the Joint Chiefs of Staff determined that the proposed Bay of Pigs invasion was highly tenuous, estimating its chances of success as roughly one in three. But in their report to President John F. Kennedy, the Chiefs wrote only that “this plan has a fair chance of success,” which Kennedy took to indicate support for the proposal (Wyden 1979, 88-90). Similarly, in his post mortem review of the space shuttle Challenger explosion, Richard Feynman (1986) found that managers and engineers held estimates of rocket failure rates that differed, on average, by a factor of one thousand. Both cases demonstrated obvious miscommunication, generated sharp criticism, and raised the possibility that major crises could have been averted if public officials had made clearer probability assessments. In some fields, vague probability assessments are deliberately encouraged by official guidelines. For instance the U.S. Director of National Intelligence’s 2015 directive on “Analytic Standards” instructs intelligence analysts to assess likelihood using “words of estimative probability” that correspond to seven different segments of the number line. This spectrum helps to mitigate extreme miscommunication as in the Bay of Pigs example, but the difference is of degree and not kind. To use this guidance properly, analysts must quantify their judgments and then coarsen those judgments into vaguer, qualitative terms. A similar set of guidelines can be found in U.S. Army doctrine on “Composite Risk Management.” There are several reasons why many scholars and practitioners advocate qualitative probability expressions, but this project focuses on two of those arguments in detail. First, many scholars and practitioners argue that quantifying probability estimates would expose analysts to undue criticism when their estimates fall on the “wrong side of maybe.” Second, clear probability assessments might constrain decision makers’ freedom of action, as explicit expressions of doubt could make policy choices more difficult to sell to the public or more challenging to defend after the fact. Both of these arguments imply that even if quantitative probability assessments are ideal in principle, bureaucratic and political incentives prevent this idea from being implemented in practice. I refer to this idea as cautionary vagueness, which I define as the use of intentionally vague probability assessments as a strategy for mitigating criticism. Though the idea of cautionary vagueness appears widely in scholarship on national security decision making, I argue that there are two main reasons to question this strategy’s effectiveness. First, even if vague probability assessments mitigate blame in some contexts, they can also mitigate credit. When probability assessments fall on the “right side of maybe,” or when risky decisions succeed, public officials may have incentives to emphasize the clarity of their probabilistic reasoning. The logic of cautionary vagueness thus supposes that the benefits of blame avoidance outweigh the costs to credit-claiming. This is plausible, but it is an empirical claim that has never been tested directly, especially in a national security context. Second, it is not clear why quantitative probability assessments should expose analysts and decision makers to greater scrutiny than employing “words of estimative probability.” It would be one thing for analysts and decision makers to avoid making probability assessments at all: but if they do express probability, does calling a conclusion “likely” really invite less criticism than making an estimate of “65 percent”? In fact, numeric assessments could even mitigate criticism in some cases by dispelling impressions of misplaced certainty. Again, it is an open empirical question as to whether these countervailing effects alleviate or intensify blame on the whole. This project aims to provide the first systematic exploration of cautionary vagueness. The theoretical purpose of this project is to translate ideas about cautionary vagueness into falsifiable hypotheses (and to explain why those hypotheses are worth scrutinizing). I then test those hypotheses using original survey experiments asking respondents to evaluate the quality of analysis and decision making.
registration_responses.q16: Probability assessments are inherently difficult to evaluate. Consider a financial analyst who states that there is a 70 percent chance that a stock price will go up. If the stock price instead goes down, then we can say that the analyst’s estimate was on the “wrong side of maybe,” but there is rarely an objective way to know how much we should attribute this particular discrepancy to bad estimation versus bad luck. Nevertheless, many people naturally criticize estimates that fall on the wrong side of maybe, assuming that uncertain outcomes should have been predictable before the fact. This is called hindsight bias (Fischhoff 1975, Tetlock and Lebow 2001). Analysts may leave probability assessments intentionally vague so as to mitigate such criticism. Scholars of national security often reference this kind of cautionary vagueness. Mark Lowenthal (2006, 128-29), a scholar with three decades’ experience in the U.S. Intelligence Community, criticizes intelligence analysts for using “weasel words” to escape criticism, arguing that this behavior represents “analytical pusillanimity.” One way in which national security may be distinct from other areas of high-stakes decision making is that decision makers might also prefer for analysts to leave probability assessments vague. Dean Acheson (1969, 375), U.S. Secretary of State under President Harry Truman, argued that public officials must often make decisions “clearer than truth,” glossing over doubts in order to defend policy choices to the public. Joshua Rovner (2011) develops a theory of intelligence-policy relations which holds that decision makers aim to cherry-pick analyses in order to oversell their policies. This behavior relates to what scholars call outcome bias: the idea that many people naturally evaluate decision makers on the basis of whether or not their actions appear to have been successful (Baron and Hershey 1988, Gurdal, Miller, and Rustichini 2013). Combined with partisan pressures, outcome bias can lead critics to seize on any information that might raise doubts about the quality of a decision. Explicitly acknowledging uncertainty about a decision’s outcome may court this kind of pushback from critical constituencies. Understanding the use of probability in national security and other areas of high-stakes decision making thus requires grappling with cautionary vagueness, whether or not one approves of the practice. Yet there are two main reasons to question whether cautionary vagueness is as effective as the conventional wisdom supposes. First, even if precise probability assessments engender blame when estimates fall on the wrong side of maybe, they may also increase credit when estimates fall on the right side of maybe. Following the successful 2011 raid on Osama bin Laden’s compound in Pakistan, for instance, President Barack Obama and his advisers described to the media how they had parsed probability assessments about the chances that Al Qaeda’s leader was living in that location, including several debates involving numeric percentages. Presumably, White House and intelligence officials believed that this information would improve public perceptions of how carefully they had handled uncertainty. President Obama remarked in an interview regarding his decision making process for the bin Laden raid that, “one of the things you learn as president is that you’re always dealing with probabilities” (Bowden 2012, 161). All participants in this debate were eager to emphasize how this decision was surrounded by uncertainty. Cautionary vagueness thus only benefits public officials if quantifying probability assessments increases blame more than it increases credit. This is plausible: some scholars posit a general negativity bias in public affairs in which blame for bad outcomes tends to stronger than credit for good outcomes (Hood 2011, 9-14). But to date, this claim has not been tested in a national security context. A second reason to question the logic of cautionary vagueness is that precise probability assessments may actually mitigate some kinds of criticism. In the case of the L’Aquila earthquake, public officials were literally put on trial for making their assessments too vague. Similarly, the 2002 National Intelligence Estimate (NIE) on Iraq’s Continuing Programs for Weapons of Mass Destruction provides an example of how imprecise analysis can plausibly increase analysts’ blame exposure. The bumper-sticker summary of the Iraq NIE is that the U.S. Intelligence Community thought it was a “slam dunk” to conclude that Saddam Hussein was pursuing nuclear weapons. But the estimate itself does not say this – in fact, the NIE’s key judgments contain no direct statements about the likelihood that Iraq was developing nuclear weapons. Many key judgments refer to Iraq pursuit of “weapons of mass destruction,” which included biological and chemical weapons in addition to nuclear weapons. The NIE states that “in the view of most agencies, Baghdad is reconstituting its nuclear weapons program,” but the estimate includes a specific dissent on this point from the U.S. State Department and does not assess of the probability that this statement is true. To be sure, the information and assumptions presented in the NIE are widely mistaken, and the estimate seems designed to convince readers to believe that Iraq was actively pursuing a nuclear bomb. But this point is mostly implied: it is not stated explicitly, let alone accompanied by a clear probability assessment. Jervis (2006), among others, has thus argued that one of the most important flaws with the Iraq NIE is not just that its arguments were wrong but that the uncertainty surrounding those estimates was left vague. In hindsight, it is impossible to say how the U.S. Intelligence Community might have quantified the probability that Saddam Hussein was pursuing nuclear weapons in 2002. But even if the NIE’s authors had assessed this probability to be as high as 80 percent or 90 percent, this could not have been construed after the fact as a “slam dunk,” and it might have generated useful debate about the sources and implications of residual doubt. Consistent with this point, post-mortem reviews of Iraq WMD intelligence written by the U.S. Senate (2004, 16), the Silberman-Robb Commission (2005, 409, 419), and the UK’s Butler Review (2004, 145) all conclude that a major lesson from the episode is the need for clearer communication of uncertainty. Moreover, it is not at all obvious why numeric percentages should court more controversy than using the “words of estimative probability” that are currently recommended by the U.S. Director of National Intelligence. Unless analysts constantly use the term “even chance,” then employing words of estimative probability always runs a risk of falling on the wrong side of maybe. The question then becomes whether assessing a probability as “65 percent” would make analysts worse off than saying that some judgment is “likely” to be true. Again, this assumption is plausible, but unsupported by systematic evidence. Hypotheses I believe that the key questions about cautionary vagueness can be translated into six testable hypotheses. These hypotheses capture arguments about how quantifying probability assessments could either exacerbate or reduce public officials’ exposure to criticism. Where relevant, I explicitly distinguish mechanisms influencing analysts versus decision makers. Following a standard distinctions in the decision sciences, I define analysts as individuals providing probability assessments and decision makers as individuals who use that information to judge prospective actions. I use the term public officials to describe both analysts and decision makers together. Hypothesis 1: Quantifying probability assessments increases criticism. Many scholars and practitioners are inherently skeptical of quantifying subjective judgments. It is thus possible that quantifying probability assessments always exposes analysts and decision makers to criticism. If true, this argument would support the argument that public officials have incentives to leave probability assessments vague. Hypothesis 2: Quantifying probability assessments increases hindsight bias. Probability assessments are especially exposed to criticism when they fall on the “wrong side of maybe.” Many scholars and practitioners believe that quantitative assessments suggest an illusion of rigor that may exacerbate such criticism. If true, this argument would support the argument that analysts have an incentive to leave probability assessments vague. Hypothesis 3: Quantifying probability assessments increases outcome bias. Decision makers are especially exposed to criticism when their actions are unsuccessful. Quantifying probability assessments could exacerbate such criticism by emphasizing how decision makers knowingly took risky actions. If true, this argument would support the argument that decision makers have an incentive to prefer that probability assessments be left vague. Hypothesis 4: Quantifying probability assessments increases credit given to analysts who fall on the “right side of maybe.” If quantifying probability assessments exposes unlucky analysts to greater criticism, then this might also facilitate credit-claiming when those assessments appear to be confirmed by subsequent events. If true, this argument would imply that analysts may not always have incentives to leave probability assessments vague. Hypothesis 5: Quantifying probability assessments increases credit given to decisions with successful outcomes. If quantifying probability assessments creates an illusion of rigor surrounding analysis and decision making, this may work to decision makers’ credit when their actions are perceived to be effective. If true, this argument would imply that decision makers may not always have incentives to prefer that probability assessments be left vague. Hypothesis 6: Quantifying probability assessments expands blame more than it expands credit. If vague probability assessments entail countervailing effects with respect to blame avoidance versus credit-claiming, then a key question is whether either of these effects is clearly stronger on net. If the “negativity bias” holds, such that quantifying probability assessments generally expands blame more than credit, then this would support the argument that public officials have incentives to leave probability estimates vague.

attributes.title: Frontoparietal Control Network and Social Anxiety Disorder

q1.value: Frontoparietal Control Network Communication Patterns in Social Anxiety Disorder

q2.value: Matthew L Dixon, James Gross, Philippe R. Goldin, richard heimberg, Andrzej sokolowski

q3.value: Social anxiety disorder (SAD) is associated with emotion regulation difficulties and aberrant neural recruitment patterns, however, less is known about potential dysfunction in large-scale brain network interactions. In this study we will examine patterns of interaction between the frontoparietal control network, default mode network, and dorsal attention network in SAD patients that underwent fMRI scanning during an autobiographical emotion provocation and regulation task.

q4.value:
(i)	Across the entire task (irrespective of condition), SAD patients will show disrupted FPCN asymmetry. SAD vs controls will show a weaker asymmetry score for FPCN-B but not FPCN-A (where asymmetry refers to mean FC with the preferred network minus mean FC with the unreferred network). This would be evident in a significant interaction in a 2 (group) x 2 (FPCN-subnetwork asymmetry score) mixed ANOVA.   
(ii)	SAD will show less condition-dependent flexibility in FPCN communication patterns. Specifically, SAD vs controls will show higher similarity (less condition-related specificity) between multivariate FPCN FC patterns with the DMN and DAN during the emotional reactivity and regulation conditions, reflecting an inability to tailor FPCN communication patterns to task demands. We will separately compute the similarity (Pearson correlation of vectorized FC values) for the reactivity and reappraisal conditions; reactivity and acceptance conditions; and reappraisal and acceptance conditions. We will then average across these values to obtain a single similarity score. This analysis will look at the FPCN as a whole, given that we hypothesized that inflexibility in SAD will be present for both subsystems. This would be evident in a significant group difference using an independent samples t-test on average similarity scores.
(iii)	Individual differences in the FPCN-B asymmetry score and FPCN similarity (inverse of flexibility) will predict baseline SAD severity scores, and baseline residualized post-treatment scores.  Specifically, using a linear regression analysis, we predict a negative relationship between the strength of the asymmetry scores and symptom severity scores as measured by the LSAS-SR and a positive relationship between similarity scores and symptom severity. Separate regressions will be run to analyze the relationship with baseline and post-treatment severity.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Between subjects design with 1 between subject factor (group: SAD vs controls) and 1 within subject factor (condition: react; reappraisal; acceptance)

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Data for this study have been collected and have been analyzed with respect to the magnitude of activation in different brain regions. However, there has been no analysis of functional connectivity (FC) patterns (the goal of the present study). Given that FC patterns have been shown to be independent of activation magnitude patterns, we are currently unaware of any FC patterns in the data at the time of writing this preregistered analysis plan.

question.value:
Participants provided informed consent in accordance with the Institutional Review Board at
Stanford University, passed MRI safety screening, were 22 to 55 years of age, were fluent in English, and were right-handed as assessed by the Edinburgh Handedness Inventory (44). Control subjects had no history of psychiatric disorders. Patients with SAD met criteria for a primary diagnosis of generalized SAD based on the Anxiety Disorders Interview Schedule for DSM-IV: Lifetime version. Clinical interviews were conducted by doctoral clinical psychologists and doctoral students in clinical psychology trained on the Anxiety Disorders Interview Schedule for DSM-IV: Lifetime version.

q13.value: Data were collected for 113 SAD participants and 35 controls (though the final sample included in data analysis will depend upon how many are removed based on our outlier exclusion criteria, described further in our methods)

question.value: We manipulated how participants processed negative self-belief statements. During the task, participants were presented with autobiographical negative self-belief statements and either: (i) reacted to and felt the sting of the statements; (ii) used a reappraisal strategy to challenge the beliefs; or (iii) used acceptance to non-judgmentally attend to their thoughts and emotions.
BOLD activation was the primary outcome variable. We also measured social anxiety severity with the Liebowitz social anxiety scale.

Our first main analysis will use a 2 (group) x 2 (FPCN subnetwork asymmetry score) mixed repeated measures ANOVA. A second main analysis will use independent samples t-tests to compare groups on a measure of average FC pattern similarity between conditions.

q21.value: The threshold for statistical significance will be p < .05, uncorrected (two-tailed), given that we are testing a restricted number of theoretically-driven hypotheses.

q22.value: Images will be specified as outliers based on a criterion of framewise displacement > .5 mm or frame-to-frame change in global signal intensity > 5 standard deviations above the mean signal for that session. Outlier images will not be deleted from the time series, but rather, modeled in the first level general linear model (GLM) in order to keep intact the temporal structure of the data. Each outlier will be represented by a single regressor in the GLM, with a 1 for the outlier time point and 0 elsewhere. Participants will be removed from additional analysis steps if have more than 20% of timepoints tagged as outliers.
