attributes.title: Harassment, Coercion, and the Agonistic Continuum: Exploring the Structure of Sexual Aggression

summary.value:
Harassment, Coercion, and the Agonistic Continuum: Exploring the Structure of Sexual Aggression
Undergraduate Program in Psychology
By Evan Moloney, with Raymond Knight, Ph.D., Advisor



Synopsis and goals of the study:
Sexual aggression, especially sexual harassment, has received a wealth of attention in recent years following the advent of the #MeToo movement and its push to increase protections against sexual misconduct for victims. However, this increased public focus has not been accompanied by any meteoric rise in the number or variety of empirical studies on sexual aggression. Classification of sexually inappropriate and violent behavior remains essentially the same as it was before #MeToo came to prominence. Sexual aggression is a generic term that is typically understood to comprise more specific, though often overlapping, behavioral typologies. Sexual harassment constitutes behaviors including insulting and degrading attitudes or behaviors toward women, unwanted sexual attention, and in some articles, sexual coercion (Fitzgerald, Gelfand & Drasgow, 1995). Sexual coercion, in turn, corresponds to the use of verbal and physical pressuring tactics to gain sex from an unwilling victim, ranging anywhere from use of sulking and charming tactics to rape (Tyler, Hoyt & Whitbeck, 1998; Knight & Sims-Knight, 2011). Sexual sadism, in contrast, describes gratuitous acts of sexual violence that go beyond what is needed to gain sex, either manifested through behaviors or through fantasies (Robertson, Graham, Krstic, & Knight, 2018). Although most published literature tends to treat these three sexual aggression typologies separately, more recent studies have suggested that they may share crucial commonalities that--if better understood--could highlight risk factors that may more accurately predict a person’s likelihood to sexually offend (Sims-Knight & Knight, 2018).
Across clinical psychopathology preceding and following the publication of DSM-5, researchers have advocated increased focus on dimensionality of traits and behaviors over traditional categorical classification models (e.g., Widiger & Costa, 1994; Ruscio & Ruscio, 2008; Zachar, 2018; Kreuger et al., 2018).The categorical nature of sexual aggression against women has been called into question (Knight, 2010), and data have shown that the presence of common risk and etiological factors may tie different ‘types’ of offender regardless of their specific offending behaviors (DeGue & DiLillo, 2004). Models that explain sexual sadism, coercion, and harassment as parts of a clear dimensional structure have been empirically generated and validated (Knight, 2010; Longpre, Guay, Knight, & Benbouriche, 2018; Longpre, Guay & Knight, 2019; Knight, 2018). So, is sexually aggressive behavior best understood (a) as separate typologies of harassment, coercion, and sadism, (b) as an overarching latent construct of sexual aggression in which harassment, coercion, and sadism are distributed and interwoven, or (c) as a combination of an underlying shared latent trait with specific variances attributable to each of the three components?
In the present study we will explore which of these three models best accounted for the responses of a large sample of college students.  We administered the Multidimensional Inventory of Development, Sex and Aggression (MIDSA, 2011) to a large sample of college students.  The MIDSA is a contingency-based, computerized assessment tool that contains scales for harassment, coercion, sadism, and many external factors that are relevant to the psychological assessment of sexually aggressive behavior.  Because it encompasses the three relevant components and multiple externally validating scales, the MIDSA provides an apt vehicle both to determine the best fit model among these constructs and to explore with structural equation modeling the covariates of the resulting best fit model.  We examine each of the components in turn.
In the first part of the present study, we will seek to present a model of sexual aggression that accounts for both the shared variances between harassing, coercive, and agonistic offending behaviors, and the specific variance within each behavioral set. We will assess the degree of shared and specific variance of behavioral items related to sexual harassment, coercion, and sadism, and to the general factor of sexual aggression overall, using harassment, coercion, and sadism scales included within the MIDSA. We hypothesize that some behavioral items will show stronger shared variance with the sexual aggression factor than they do variance with the specific category governing their MIDSA scales. General and specific factors will be assessed through confirmatory factor analysis, in one-factor, correlated-factors, and bifactor models. We expect all models to show good fit, given the substantial research suggesting construct validity for the  behavioral typologies of sexual harassment, coercion, and sadism, and the aforementioned data that supports a shared variance between all types of sexual aggression. However, we expect that the bifactor model should best account for both the specific and shared variance within the behavioral scales in question. The bifactor model’s resulting general factor will include items that are more indicative of a latent continuum, one that should include items already outlined by the Agonistic Continuum developed by Knight et al., whereas the specific factors will include items that do not fit into a broad continuum of sexual aggression.
Hypothesis I: Competing correlated-factors, one-factor, and bifactor confirmatory models of sexual aggression as measured by harassment, coercion, and sadism scales will all yield good fit, but the bifactor model will yield the best overall fit among the three.
In order to validate the potential models we aim to generate in this study, we will use several external validator measures drawn from MIDSA scales that do not primarily relate to sexually aggressive behaviors. Based upon prior research, we set expectations as to which MIDSA scales will best capture the domain of sexual aggression, and which will better capture only one of our expected specific factors of harassment, coercion, and the Agonistic Continuum. 
Hypothesis II: Several external validator scales will covary most strongly with the bifactor model’s general core factor of aggression, whereas others will covary most closely with each of its potential specific factors: the combination of harassment and coercion, and the Agonistic Continuum.
Hypothesis IIa: Several external validator scales will covary closely with the general factor of sexual aggression, including Juvenile Delinquency, Juvenile Assaultive Behavior, Adult Conduct Disorder, Adult Nonsexual Offenses.
Hypothesis IIb: Several external validator scales will covary closely with a specific factor combining sexual harassment and coercion, including Hostility toward Women and Hypermasculinity, Hypersexuality, Sexual Preoccupation, Impulsivity, the juvenile and adult drug and alcohol abuse scales, and Pornography Use.
Hypothesis IIc: Several external validator scales will covary with the specific factor of sexual sadism and paraphilic coercion that constitutes the Agonistic Continuum, including Callousness/Risk, problematic sexuality (i.e., Sexual Compulsivity and paraphilic fantasy and behavior), and Expressive Aggression.
We will analyze data primarily in MPlus Version 8.3. If necessary, supplementary analyses will be carried out in IBM SPSS 26 and in R version 3.6.2.

registration_responses.summary:
Harassment, Coercion, and the Agonistic Continuum: Exploring the Structure of Sexual Aggression
Undergraduate Program in Psychology
By Evan Moloney, with Raymond Knight, Ph.D., Advisor



Synopsis and goals of the study:
Sexual aggression, especially sexual harassment, has received a wealth of attention in recent years following the advent of the #MeToo movement and its push to increase protections against sexual misconduct for victims. However, this increased public focus has not been accompanied by any meteoric rise in the number or variety of empirical studies on sexual aggression. Classification of sexually inappropriate and violent behavior remains essentially the same as it was before #MeToo came to prominence. Sexual aggression is a generic term that is typically understood to comprise more specific, though often overlapping, behavioral typologies. Sexual harassment constitutes behaviors including insulting and degrading attitudes or behaviors toward women, unwanted sexual attention, and in some articles, sexual coercion (Fitzgerald, Gelfand & Drasgow, 1995). Sexual coercion, in turn, corresponds to the use of verbal and physical pressuring tactics to gain sex from an unwilling victim, ranging anywhere from use of sulking and charming tactics to rape (Tyler, Hoyt & Whitbeck, 1998; Knight & Sims-Knight, 2011). attributes.title: Dehumanization-type Stereotypes as a Mediator between Generalized Racial Essentialism and Punishment
attributes.description: The proposed study intends to investigate the relationship between generalized racial essentialism and punishment, using dehumanization as a mediator. Two racial groups, Asians and Blacks, will be used to assess this relationship. Generalized racial essentialism is comprised of two subtypes detailed in the following pages: essentialist entitativity and essentialist naturalness. Dehumanization is the denial of someone’s humanity. The objective of the study is to determine if the punishment applied to Asians and Blacks is contingent upon how others conceptualize social groups, particularly if they believe those groups are cohesive and naturally occurring. Additionally, the study will explore if believing those groups possess a nonhuman nature is important in determining how to punish a group member for an offense. The proposed study would inform the literature on punishment inside and outside of the criminal justice system, as well as the significance of explanations of racial group formation.

q1.value: Dehumanization-type Stereotypes as a Mediator between Generalized Racial Essentialism and Punishment

q3.value: This study investigates the relationship between generalized racial essentialism and punishment, using dehumanization as a mediator. Two racial groups, Asians and Blacks, will be used to assess this relationship. Generalized racial essentialism is comprised of two sub-types detailed in the following pages: essentialist entitativity and essentialist naturalness. Dehumanization is the denial of someone’s humanity. The objective of the study is to determine if the punishment applied to Asians and Blacks is contingent upon how others conceptualize social groups, particularly if they believe those groups are cohesive and naturally occurring. Additionally, this study explores if believing those groups possess a nonhuman nature is important in determining how to punish a group member for an offense.

q4.value:
1.	High levels of Essentialist Entitativity will be positively related to participants selecting traits consistent with animalistic dehumanization for Blacks.

2.	High levels of Essentialist Naturalness will be positively related to participants selecting traits consistent with mechanistic dehumanization for Asians. 

3.	Animalistic/Mechanistic dehumanization stereotypes will act as a mediator in the relationship between Essentialist Entitativity/ Essentialist Naturalness, respectively, and the administration of punishment. 

4.	High levels of generalized racial essentialism will be more positively related to, compared to Essentialist Entitativity, selecting animalistic dehumanization stereotypes for Blacks.

5.	High levels of generalized racial essentialism will be more positively related to, compared to Essentialist Naturalness, selecting mechanistic dehumanization stereotypes for Asians.

6.	Animalistic/Mechanistic dehumanization stereotypes will act as a mediator in the relationship between generalized racial essentialism and the administration of punishment.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We have a between subjects design with 4 factors: Essentialism with 3 levels (Essentialist Entitativity, Essentialist Naturalness, Generalized); Race with 2 levels (Black, Asian); Dehumanization-type stereotypes with 3 levels (Animalistic, Mechanistic, Neutral); Punishment (1 [not likely at all] to 6 [very likely]).

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through Amazon's Mechanical Turk. Eligible participants will be given permission to take the survey after completing a screener survey (see Screener Survey file). Participants will be paid approximately $2.00 for agreeing to participate. Only responses from White participants will be included in the final data set for analysis. Participants must be at least 18 years old.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 300 White participants.

q14.value:
In place of a power analysis, the effect sizes from previous studies with similar topics (e.g. essentialism, dehumanization, punishment) will be used as justification. 
Results from Andrighetto et al. (2014) will be used to show the potential relationship from Dehumanization and  Essentialism to Punishment. As part of a preliminary study using 54 participants, animalistic dehumanization was attributed to Haitians at a greater rate than Japanese people (ηp2 = 0.41). Mechanistic dehumanization was attributed to Japanese people at a greater rate than Haitians (ηp2 = 0.61). In the primary study, animalistic dehumanization predicted lower levels of empathy ( p = 0.04) and a lower willingness to help Haitians ( p = 0.03). Mechanistic dehumanization predicted lower levels of empathy (p = 0.01) and a lower willingness to help Japanese people (p = 0.03). 
Results from Bastian and Haslam (2006) will be used to show the potential relationship from Essentialism to Stereotypes. Researchers found that, among their sample of 114 participants, essentialist beliefs predicted positive (r = .22, p < .05) and negative (r = .36, p < .001) stereotypes. 
Results from Goff et al. (2008) will be used to show the potential relationship from Race and Dehumanization to Punishment. In a retroactive look at 153 cases where defendants were eligible for the death penalty (15 White defendants, 138 Black defendants), researchers looked at how defendants were portrayed in the media. They found that words associated with apes (e.g. animal, beast, savage) were used for Black defendants more than for White defendants (η2 = 0.03). Black defendants who were sentenced to death were more likely to be portrayed using words associated with apes than Whites (η2 = 0.04).

question.value:
The Essentialism variable will be assessed using the the Essentialist Entitativity and Essentialist Naturalness scales used in Roets and Van Hiel (2011; see Appendices A and B file). Both scales are modified from being a seven-point scale to six-point; this is to prevent participants from selecting the middle/neutral option. For each question, the phrase “racial groups” will be replaced with the race-neutral phrase “social groups.” The ratings will be from 1 (completely disagree) to 6 (completely agree), except for reverse-coded questions. The results from the exploratory factor analysis conducted by Roets and Van Hiel (2011) will be presented as justification for using the Essentialist Entitativity and Essentialist Naturalness scales. The informativeness, uniformity, and inherence items of the Essentialist Entitativity scale yielded primary loadings ranging from 0.37 to 0.75 on the EE structure. The immutability, naturalness, discreteness, necessity, and stability items of the EN scale yielded primary loadings ranging from 0.25 to 0.61. 

The Dehumanization-type Stereotypes variable will be assessed using the diagnostic ratio (DR) approach. A total of 18 traits will be displayed: 6 represent animalistic, 6 represent mechanistic, and 6 will be designated as neutral (see Appendix C). The traits were adapted from the model of dehumanization presented in Haslam (2006). Ratings for each trait will range from 0 to 100% in ten-percent increments. Four groups will be assessed: Whites, Blacks, Asians, and the General U.S. population. Each trait will receive a diagnostic ratio. The ratio will be formed by dividing the percentage for each trait for Asians and Blacks, respectively, by the percentage for the general U.S. population. Every score will be given a +1 in order to avoid the possibility of obtaining a zero in the denominator. Each DR will be centered at 0. Positive scores will indicate a stereotype for the racial group; negative scores will indicate a stereotype for the general population. 

The outcome variable, Punishment, will be assessed by requesting participants assign punishments after reading a scenario text. Two scenarios will be used where participants will act in a role: prison warden and college dean. Each scenario will have an “actor” with five punishments (see Appendix D). The prison warden scenario will take place in a medium-security prison where a prisoner is involved in a physical altercation, theft, and other infractions. The college dean scenario will take place in a medium-size college where a student is involved in cheating, bullying, and other college violations. For each punishment, participants will be asked to rate the likelihood that they would administer the option (e.g. “How likely are you to expel her?”). These likelihood scores will be Likert-type scales from one (not likely at all) to six (very likely). Two scenarios per racial group will be presented.  Each punishment option will be given a degree of severity, ranging from one (least severe) to five (most severe); these ratings will not be advertised to the participants. Some participants will see one set of scenarios (six) while others will see another set of scenarios (six).

The Essentialist  Entitativity scale and Essentialist Naturalness scale responses will be averaged, respectively to yield two separate scores per participant. An average Generalized Essentialism score will be calculated by averaging the responses for  both the Essentialist  Entitativity and Essentialist Naturalness scales. 
For the Dehumanization-type Stereotypes variable: Each trait will receive a diagnostic ratio. The ratio will be formed by dividing the percentage for each trait for Asians and Blacks, respectively, by the percentage for the general U.S. population. Every score will be given a +1 in order to avoid the possibility of obtaining a zero in the denominator. Each DR will be centered at 0. Positive scores will indicate a stereotype for the racial group; negative scores will indicate a stereotype for the general population. A confirmatory analysis will be conducted to determine if the traits assigned to each group (Animalistic, Mechanistic, Neutral) load onto their specified group. 
For the punishment variable, each racial group will receive a total punishment score calculated across scenarios; a punishment score will also be calculated for each scenario.

For the Dehumanization-type stereotype variable:  A confirmatory analysis will be conducted to determine if the traits assigned to each group (Animalistic, Mechanistic, Neutral) load onto their specified group. 

Parallel mediation modeling using PROCESS Macro for SPSS will be used to assess the function of dehumanization-specific stereotypes as a mediator. Essentialism will be split into Essentialist Entitativity , Essentialist Naturalness, and its Generalized form. Dehumanization-specific stereotypes will be split according to their assigned group. Each model has the punishment score for each racial group (see Appendix E).

q20.value: The Dehumanization-type Stereotype variable, which uses the diagnostic ratio measure, requires a transformation. Each trait will receive a diagnostic ratio. The ratio will be formed by dividing the percentage for each trait for Asians and Blacks, respectively, by the percentage for the general U.S. population. Every score will be given a +1 in order to avoid the possibility of obtaining a zero in the denominator. Each DR will be centered at 0. Positive scores will indicate a stereotype for the racial group; negative scores will indicate a stereotype for the general population.

q22.value: Responses from participants who do not identify as White will be excluded from analysis. Only participants who have completed all questions will be used in the analysis. Outliers will be included in the analysis. An awareness check ("Please select four") will be included.

q23.value: Missing/incomplete data will be dropped before conducting the analysis.

q25.value:
Andrighetto, L., Baldissarri, C., Lattanzio, S., Loughnan, S., & Volpato, C. (2014). Human‐itarian aid? Two forms of dehumanization and willingness to help after natural disasters. British Journal of Social Psychology, 53(3), 573–584. https://doi.org/10.1111/bjso.12066

Bastian, B., & Haslam, N. (2006). Psychological essentialism and stereotype endorsement. Journal of Experimental Social Psychology, 42(2), 228–235. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jesp.2005.03.003

Goff, P. A., Eberhardt, J. L., Williams, M. J., & Jackson, M. C. (2008). Not yet human: Implicit knowledge, historical dehumanization, and contemporary consequences. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 94(2), 292–306. https://doi.org/10.1037/0022-3514.94.2.292

Roets, A., & Van Hiel, A. (2011). The role of need for closure in essentialist entitativity beliefs and prejudice: An epistemic needs approach to racial categorization. British Journal of Social Psychology, 50(1), 52–73. https://doi.org/10.1348/014466610X491567

For each punishment, participants will be asked to rate the likelihood that they would administer the option (e.g. “How likely are you to expel her?”). These likelihood scores will be Likert-type scales from one (not likely at all) to six (very likely). Two scenarios per racial group will be presented.  Each punishment option will be given a degree of severity, ranging from one (least severe) to five (most severe); these ratings will not be advertised to the participants. Some participants will see one set of scenarios (six) while others will see another set of scenarios (six).
registration_responses.q18.question:
The Essentialist  Entitativity scale and Essentialist Naturalness scale responses will be averaged, respectively to yield two separate scores per participant. An average Generalized Essentialism score will be calculated by averaging the responses for  both the Essentialist  Entitativity and Essentialist Naturalness scales. 
For the Dehumanization-type Stereotypes variable: Each trait will receive a diagnostic ratio. The ratio will be formed by dividing the percentage for each trait for Asians and Blacks, respectively, by the percentage for the general U.S. population. Every score will be given a +1 in order to avoid the possibility of obtaining a zero in the denominator. Each DR will be centered at 0. Positive scores will indicate a stereotype for the racial group; negative scores will indicate a stereotype for the general population. A confirmatory analysis will be conducted to determine if the traits assigned to each group (Animalistic, Mechanistic, Neutral) load onto their specified group. 
For the punishment variable, each racial group will receive a total punishment score calculated across scenarios; a punishment score will also be calculated for each scenario.
registration_responses.q19.question:
For the Dehumanization-type stereotype variable:  A confirmatory analysis will be conducted to determine if the traits assigned to each group (Animalistic, Mechanistic, Neutral) load onto their specified group. 

Parallel mediation modeling using PROCESS Macro for SPSS will be used to assess the function of dehumanization-specific stereotypes as a mediator. Essentialism will be split into Essentialist Entitativity , Essentialist Naturalness, and its Generalized form. Dehumanization-specific stereotypes will be split according to their assigned group. Each model has the punishment score for each racial group (see Appendix E).

attributes.title: Now you see me, now you shouldn’t: the distorting effect of context reinstatement on memory for own- and other-race faces

q1.value: Now you see me, now you shouldn’t: the distorting effect of context reinstatement on memory for own- and other-race faces (Amendment 1)

q3.value:
Reinstating the encoding context during memory retrieval is thought to boost accuracy in memory performance (Evans, Marcon, & Meissner, 2009; Fisher & Schreiber, 2017; Godden & Baddeley, 1975; Smith & Vela, 2001). This beneficial effect of context has been attributed to the overlap between encoding and retrieval cues; participants form unique item-context associations during encoding that can be triggered by context cues during retrieval (Murnane, Phelps, & Malmberg, 1999; Tulving & Thomson, 1973). 

A recent study by Doss, Picart and Gallo (2018) has argued that for this same reason, context reinstatement can also systematically distort memory: what we will refer to as the ‘context illusion effect’. In this study, we explore the extent that this illusion might extend to same and other-race faces. 

Black and White participants will encode Black and White faces superimposed on background scenes (serving as context). Thereafter they will complete a retrieval task in which the faces will either be those the participant previously encoded, new faces or lure faces - faces that are similar to but not the same as previously encoded faces. Context will be reinstated at retrieval for half of the same and lure faces and switched for the other half. Face lures will be generated using Java Psychomorph software (Tiddeman & Perrett, 2002). We expect that participants will falsely recognize lure faces and that this will be greater when context is reinstated than when it is switched. We also expect an interaction effect, with larger context effect for own-race than other-race faces.

Note: This is an amendment (Amendment 1) to our original pre-registration. Data outcomes for White participants in the original pre-registered project suggested that the difficulty of the face memory task may compromise our ability to meaningfully interpret context reinstatement outcomes (i.e., the ability to differentiate studied and similar faces from memory was near chance in some conditions, potentially complicating our ability to draw firm conclusions from the impact of our other measured variables — race and context — on face memory). In this amendment, we have added a second study with a modified design. The only change in this experiment is that participants will complete their episodic memory task in 4 blocks rather than 1 large block, making the task easier for participants while not affecting the statistical power identified for this research question. Results from both experiments will be analyzed and reported in the same way. This amendment has been created prior to data collection for study 2.

q4.value:
(1) We hypothesize that false recognition of novel faces that are perceptually similar to studied faces will be greater when context is reinstated: Context reinstatement will activate face-context associations that can impact face memory, analogous to the context illusion effects on object-memory observed by Doss, Picart and Gallo (2018). 

(2) Doss, Picart and Gallo (2018) attributed the context illusion effect to the formation of conceptual item-context associations during encoding, later triggered by context cues at retrieval and misattributed to the novel object. If this is so, we can present the following hypothesis towards the interaction of Context Reinstatement and the Own Race Bias: the impact of context will be greater on own-race faces since they would enjoy richer face-context conceptual associations. However, it is also possible that the context illusion will be greater with other-race faces than same-race faces, due to more perceptual confusions with other-race faces. Finally, it is possible that both these processes are at play and cancel eachother out. We present these as competing hypotheses towards an interaction effect. 

(3) The above-mentioned interaction effects will be observed even while analyzing high-confidence responses, suggesting a false memory effect rather than a guessing effect (Doss, Picart, & Gallo, 2018). 

(4) The above-mentioned interaction effects will be the result of conceptual links formed between target faces and contexts, and not mere perceptual familiarity.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Note: This is an amendment (Amendment 1) to our original pre-registration. In this amendment, we have added a second study with a modified design, such that participants will complete their episodic memory task in 4 blocks rather than 1 large block, making the task easier for participants while not affecting the statistical power identified for this research question. The following details apply to study 1 as well as study 2.

Our experimental design will differ from our statistical design. The paradigm itself will be a 2X2x3 within-subjects design with all participants undergoing the following conditions: race membership (is the participant of the same race as target face stimulus, or other race), context reinstatement (is the context reinstated or switched at retrieval) and stimulus face (is the face stimulus at retrieval a target, a similar lure or a dissimilar lure). 

The statistical design will be 2x2 within subjects with the following independent variables: race membership (is the target face stimulus of the same race as the participant, or other race) and context reinstatement (is the context reinstated or switched at retrieval). We will be interested in main effects as well as interaction effects if any between race membership and context reinstatement. These analyses will be carried out and reported separately for White and Black participants. If the outcomes for White and Black participants are in agreement (i.e, memory performance for Black faces and White faces by outgroup members follow similar patterns), we will also collapse across participant race and report outcomes. 

The paradigm aims to replicate Doss, Picart and Gallo (2018) to the best extent possible and thereby the 2x2x3 experimental design. The statistical design speaks to our confirmatory hypotheses and is therefore 2x2 with an interest in the interaction effect specified (we will be interested in outcomes for similar lures, which pertains directly to our confirmatory hypotheses, but also outcomes for targets). We propose to carry out our analyses independently for White and Black participants at the outset (i.e, memory performance for Black faces and White faces by outgroup members) because White target faces have shown better memory performance across participant races than Black target faces (Gross, 2009). 

Face stimulus subsets will be counterbalanced across context reinstatement and stimulus face conditions. A separate subset of face stimuli will serve as dissimilar lures. Context / scene subsets will be counterbalanced across target race membership. In study 2 (Amendment 1 to pre-registration), the stimulus list will be divided into subsets such that the aforementioned counter-balancing remains as is.

q9.value: We will use block randomization: Each participant will be randomly assigned (with equal probability) to one of eight equally sized, predetermined versions based on the counterbalancing described in the 'Study Design' section. Random assignment will be conducted by the task program.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Note: This is an amendment (Amendment 1) to our original pre-registration. In this amendment, we have added a second study with a modified design, such that participants will complete their episodic memory task in 4 blocks rather than 1 large block, making the task easier for participants while not affecting the statistical power identified for this research question. The amendment has been created prior to data collection for study 2, and the following details apply to study 1 as well as study 2.

For the present study, a set of White participants and a set of Black participants will be recruited on Amazon MTurk. Both male and female participants will be employed. Participants will be between 18 and 30 years of age (a young adult population) and will all have been born in, and will be presently be residing in, the United States. Participants will be warned at the outset (Turk Prime advert) that they will need to have normal / corrected-to-normal vision to complete the task successfully.

q13.value: For the present study (as well as study 2; Amendment 1 to pre-registration), 72 White and 72 Black participants are planned to be recruited.

q14.value: To identify the sample size, we conducted a Power Analysis using the PANGEA package (v0.2), publicly available at https://jakewestfall.shinyapps.io/pangea/ (Westfall, in preparation). Our primary statistical analysis will be a 2 (face race: own, other) x 2 context (reinstated, switched), with the expectation that there will be a main effect of context (reinstated; switched) that is similar (does not interact) for targets and lures, as in Doss, Picart and Gallo (2018). Thus, we aim to power the predicted 2x2 interaction between race (own, other) and context (reinstated switched), collapsing across item type. As this is the first study to our knowledge that explicitly examines intersections between the Other Race Bias and the Context Illusion effect with a 2x2 within-subjects design, the variance and effect size parameters were not possible to predict a priori. Therefore, we used the default variance parameters in PANGEA (var[error] = 0.333 var(P*R*F*C) = 0.083) to estimate power for a 2 (Race: Own, Other) X 2 (Context: Reinstated, Switched) interaction consisting of 72 participants (entered as random factor), and 16 analyzable trials per condition. Results suggested that a sample of 72 participants would be sufficiently powered to detect a significant interaction effect of Status and Race at an effect size as small as d=0.20, 1 – β = 0.805. Therefore, for the present study, 72 White and 72 Black participants are planned to be recruited.

q15.value: Data will be monitored regularly for any eliminations based on attention, captcha, comprehension, Geo IP and/or manipulation checks. Data collection will be terminated when at least 72 White and 72 Black participants successfully complete the paradigm and its supplementary questionnaires. If there are surplus responses on either race, we will run two sets of analyses - one with all usable data, and one with matched / equal data counts for each race.

question.value: Manipulated variables will be race-membership (whether the target stimulus face is of the same race as the participant or the other race), context reinstatement (whether the context is reinstated or switched during the retrieval phase) and face stimulus (whether the face presented at retrieval is the same face as was encoded or a similar lure). While the first two manipulated variables will be employed as part of our statistical design, the third will be employed to measure outcomes for two categories of memory items - targets and similar lures.

As mentioned in the 'Study Information - Description' section, Black and White participants will encode (an equal number of) Black and White Faces superimposed on background scenes (serving as context). 

Thereafter they will complete a retrieval task in which they will again be presented with Black and White Faces superimposed on background scenes. Participants will be presented with an equal number of Black and White faces for each of the following conditions: (target face with context reinstated), (target face with context switched), (lure face with context reinstated), (lure face with context switched) and (new face). For each face viewed by the participants in the retrieval task, they will respond to the following questions: 

1. Focusing only on faces, is this face the same face, a similar face or a new face? 
2. How confident do you feel about your decision? 
3. If you said same or similar, is this a matched scene or a mismatched scene? 
4. Tell us what helped you remembered the face: association or perception? 

At the outset the 'association' and 'perception' options will be explained to participants as follows: 
Association: I remembered forming a link between the face and the background (eg: “He looks like that person I saw on the beach last Friday”) 
Perception: I did not form any links – just remembered seeing that face on that background (eg: “ This image was superimposed on a beach photo”) 

Participants will respond by pressing appropriate letters on their keyboard. There will be no time limits enforced on participant response to these questions. 

Measured variables will be p(“same”) as well as p(“same” AND high confidence) with face stimuli, p(“matched” | "same" OR "similar") for face-scene stimuli and p("associations" | "same" OR "similar") to investigate approach. These variables will be measured for each experimental condition and each combination of experimental conditions. Another measured variable will be the discrimination index d for faces defined as p("same")|target - p("same")|similar lure). 

Note: This is an amendment (Amendment 1) to our original pre-registration. Per this amendment, we will add a second study with a modified design, such that participants will complete their episodic memory task in 4 blocks rather than 1 large block, making the task easier for participants while not affecting the statistical power identified for this research question.
We do not plan to calculate any indices apart from what we have otherwise specified in the Design, Variables and Analysis sections.

Note: This is an amendment (Amendment 1) to our original pre-registration. In this amendment, we have added a second study with a modified design, such that participants will complete their episodic memory task in 4 blocks rather than 1 large block, making the task easier for participants while not affecting the statistical power identified for this research question. The following details apply to study 1 as well as study 2.

Dependent Variables will be analyzed using a 2 (Race: own, other) x 2 (Context: Reinstated, Switched) within-participants linear mixed-effects models: 

lmer(DV ~ Context*Race + (Context*Race|subject), data = [...]) or if this model does not converge, lmer(DV ~ Context*Race + (1|subject), data = [...]) 

Own Race will be coded as 0.5, other race as -0.5. 

Context Reinstated will be coded as 0.5, switched as -0.5. 

Target will be coded as 0.5, similar lure as -0.5: We will be interested in outcomes for similar lures (which is related directly to our confirmatory hypotheses) as well as outcomes for targets. 

In the case of an interaction between race and context for any dependent variable, we will run planned contrasts using paired-samples t tests run on separate levels of an experimental factor implicated in the interaction.

q20.value: There are no transformation plans made priori other than as listed in the Design, Variable and Analysis sections.

q21.value: We will be using two-tailed tests and will acknowledge significance effects at p less than 0.05. We will also report confidence intervals (Cumming, 2014).

q22.value:
Note: This is an amendment (Amendment 1) to our original pre-registration. In this amendment, we have added a second study with a modified design, such that participants will complete their episodic memory task in 4 blocks rather than 1 large block, making the task easier for participants while not affecting the statistical power identified for this research question. The following details apply to study 1 as well as study 2.

Paradigms and surveys used in this study will include a bot-capture question (Captcha question), task instructions comprehension questions (for the Memory Task paradigm), attention check questions (face with number on them - participant is expected to type in that number instead of making a memory decision) and Geo-IP checks. Participants who fail the bot check or show a Geo IP outside of the United States will be excluded from our analyses. Also participants who fail 1 or more attention checks / 1 or more task comprehension checks will be eliminated from analyses. Finally, participants who do not complete the entire paradigm or are not paid for their participation will also be excluded from analyses. 

The present study will also employ outlier analyses: We will conduct the main analysis on all participants (excluding data that meet the above criteria and participants with missing data but not excluding outliers based on memory performance). We will however perform a secondary analysis that excludes poor memorizers. We define this as participants with negative accuracy on the memory task (“same” responses to all targets (averaged across race and context) minus “same” response to all dissimilar lures (averaged across race)). If participants say “same” more often to dissimilar lures than to targets, on average, then they possibly are not doing the task right (i.e., they have no memory for the targets). Yet, we will first analyze all data (With a large enough data set such as ours, small numbers of outliers may not substantively affect results of analyses; Luszcz, Bryan & Kent, 1997) and perform outlier exclusion as secondary analyses.

q23.value: We will not use any participant responses with incomplete or missing data. Compensation will require successful completion of the task.

q24.value:
We aim to understand the influence of Social Psychological factors such as participant attitudes towards other racial groups, participant inter-racial contact and participant motivation to respond without prejudice. These data will be collected as post-task questionnaires to the Episodic Memory Task and will be employed for Exploratory Analyses. 

We will also examine on an exploratory basis, the participant response latencies to different conditions in the experiment. Another exploratory analysis of interest will be the conditional probability of memory performance for faces given accurate memory performance for scenes. This is because our ongoing studies indicate that the context illusion may be larger when context memory is accurate. 

A final exploratory analysis we will run will be to understand the interaction of this phenomenon with target face race as memorized by outgroup members (in other words, a 2x2x2x2 statistical design for exploratory analyses). We expect that the context illusion x other race bias interaction effect may be smaller for Black participants viewing White faces (Gross, 2009). This exploratory analysis will also help us better understand outcomes when pooling across all of the subjects (regardless of their race) - we expect that the black face stimulus set (as memorized by White participants) will be more difficult to differentiate between the same/similar/new categories. 

Apart from the frequential statistics we describe in this pre-registration, we also aim to employ Bayesian statistics for exploratory analyses of our data.

As mentioned in the 'Study Information - Description' section, Black and White participants will encode (an equal number of) Black and White Faces superimposed on background scenes (serving as context). 

Thereafter they will complete a retrieval task in which they will again be presented with Black and White Faces superimposed on background scenes. Participants will be presented with an equal number of Black and White faces for each of the following conditions: (target face with context reinstated), (target face with context switched), (lure face with context reinstated), (lure face with context switched) and (new face). For each face viewed by the participants in the retrieval task, they will respond to the following questions: 

1. Focusing only on faces, is this face the same face, a similar face or a new face? 
2. How confident do you feel about your decision? 
3. If you said same or similar, is this a matched scene or a mismatched scene? 
4. Tell us what helped you remembered the face: association or perception? 

At the outset the 'association' and 'perception' options will be explained to participants as follows: 
Association: I remembered forming a link between the face and the background (eg: “He looks like that person I saw on the beach last Friday”) 
Perception: I did not form any links – just remembered seeing that face on that background (eg: “ This image was superimposed on a beach photo”) 

Participants will respond by pressing appropriate letters on their keyboard. There will be no time limits enforced on participant response to these questions. 

Measured variables will be p(“same”) as well as p(“same” AND high confidence) with face stimuli, p(“matched” | "same" OR "similar") for face-scene stimuli and p("associations" | "same" OR "similar") to investigate approach. These variables will be measured for each experimental condition and each combination of experimental conditions. Another measured variable will be the discrimination index d for faces defined as p("same")|target - p("same")|similar lure). 

Note: This is an amendment (Amendment 1) to our original pre-registration. Per this amendment, we will add a second study with a modified design, such that participants will complete their episodic memory task in 4 blocks rather than 1 large block, making the task easier for participants while not affecting the statistical power identified for this research question.
registration_responses.q18.question: We do not plan to calculate any indices apart from what we have otherwise specified in the Design, Variables and Analysis sections.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Note: This is an amendment (Amendment 1) to our original pre-registration. In this amendment, we have added a second study with a modified design, such that participants will complete their episodic memory task in 4 blocks rather than 1 large block, making the task easier for participants while not affecting the statistical power identified for this research question. The following details apply to study 1 as well as study 2.

Dependent Variables will be analyzed using a 2 (Race: own, other) x 2 (Context: Reinstated, Switched) within-participants linear mixed-effects models: 

lmer(DV ~ Context*Race + (Context*Race|subject), data = [...]) or if this model does not converge, lmer(DV ~ Context*Race + (1|subject), data = [...]) 

Own Race will be coded as 0.5, other race as -0.5. 

Context Reinstated will be coded as 0.5, switched as -0.5. 

Target will be coded as 0.5, similar lure as -0.5: We will be interested in outcomes for similar lures (which is related directly to our confirmatory hypotheses) as well as outcomes for targets. 

In the case of an interaction between race and context for any dependent variable, we will run planned contrasts using paired-samples t tests run on separate levels of an experimental factor implicated in the interaction.
